gco:nilReason="inapplicable"/>                   </gmd:CI_ResponsibleParty>                </gmd:citedResponsibleParty>                <gmd:presentationForm>                   <gmd:CI_PresentationFormCode codeList="http://www.isotc211.org/2005/resources/Codelist/gmxCodelists.xml#CI_PresentationFormCode"                                                codeListValue="mapDigital">mapDigital</gmd:CI_PresentationFormCode>                </gmd:presentationForm>             </gmd:CI_Citation>          </gmd:citation>          <gmd:abstract>             <gco:CharacterString>These data consist of vector line segments tagged with elevation derived from the LOSCO/FEMA LIDAR five meter DEM data set for seven watershed basins in the Louisiana Coastal Zone. This project produced over 50,000 linear miles of vector tagged shoreline covering 7,150 sq. mi. of coastal zone.</gco:CharacterString>          </gmd:abstract>          <gmd:purpose>             <gco:CharacterString>The project was designed to build upon the recently completed, LOSCO/FEMA, LIDAR topographic mapping project in south Louisiana. Over 600 tiles of LIDAR data (quarter quadrangles) covering approximately 11,000 square miles were collected in the Louisiana coastal zone, representing a $2.6 million investment by FEMA and the state. The vertical accuracy and resolution of LIDAR derived elevation products greatly exceed the outdated topographic information currently in use from USGS topographic maps. In addition, LIDAR provides remote access to Louisiana's extensive coastal wetland and swamp forest environments, not easily reached by ground survey teams. LIDAR offers many advantages and product derivatives, which will be significant for Louisiana's low relief and remote wetland environments. An important initial step in preparing this topographic dataset for use in various coastal research and management applications was to derive an elevation tagged shoreline for the coastal zone. An elevation tagged shoreline will be particularly useful for oil spill contingency planning and response activities such as mapping the extent and elevation of oil spill impacts. It could be utilized for oil spill remediation and restoration activities. This effort will also provide an important component for the modeling and use of dispersants in tidal and channelized areas. This project resulted in the methodology to develop and derive an elevation tagged vector shoreline (land/water interface) from the five meter resolution LIDAR data within the Louisiana coastal zone. Over 50,000 linear miles of vector tagged shoreline covering 7,150 sq. mi. of coastal zone were produced. Due to the size of the data set, it was decided to deliver the results aggregated by the seven watershed basins containing Lidar data within the legally defined coastal zone. To preclude running the numerous processes and procedures separately on each of the more than 500 quarterquad panels, they were aggregated by primary watershed basin to be processed individually. The final products for this project include seven elevation tagged shoreline shapefiles cut to basin boundaries within the coastal zone, which provide natural topographic breaks. This procedure permitted breaking up the enormous project into manageable, efficient file sizes and geographically distinct units. The Mississippi River Basin was excluded due to the inconsistent and patchy Lidar coverage in the region. These datasets are available for download at http://lagic.lsu.edu/loscoweb.</gco:CharacterString>          </gmd:purpose>          <gmd:status>             <gmd:MD_ProgressCode codeList="http://www.isotc211.org/2005/resources/Codelist/gmxCodelists.xml#MD_ProgressCode"                                  codeListValue="completed">completed</gmd:MD_ProgressCode> The grid code value was derived from the original floating point LIDAR DEM cell value, z, by (z+99)*10. The original DEM cell values are in decimal feet.</gco:CharacterString>                </gmd:descriptor>                <!--FGDC content not mapped to ISO. <gmd:DQ_AbsoluteExternalPositionalAccuracy>                <gmd:nameOfMeasure>                   <gco:CharacterString>Vertical Positional Accuracy</gco:CharacterString>                </gmd:nameOfMeasure>                <gmd:measureDescription>                   <gco:CharacterString>The LIDAR systems being used in the Louisiana project are accurate to 18.5 cm RMSE, depending upon land cover, and will support contours of 1'-2' vertical map accuracy standards. These accuracies meet FEMA standards for floodplain reevaluation studies and map modernization programs designed to update the Flood Insurance Rate Maps (FIRM).The laser ranging device is sensitive to 0.2' elevation change supporting high-resolution hydraulic model applications for flood plain computations in low relief and coastal environments.</gco:CharacterString>                </gmd:measureDescription>                <gmd:result>                   <gmd:DQ_QuantitativeResult>                      <gmd:valueUnit>                         <gml:BaseUnit gml:id="d36105e245">                            <gml:identifier codeSpace="local">meters</gml:identifier>                            <gml:unitsSystem xlink:href="http://www.bipm.org/en/si/"/>                         </gml:BaseUnit>                      </gmd:valueUnit>                      <gmd:value gco:nilReason="missing"/>                   </gmd:DQ_QuantitativeResult>                </gmd:result> </gmd:DQ_ConceptualConsistency>          </gmd:report>          <gmd:lineage>             <gmd:LI_Lineage>                <gmd:processStep>                   <gmi:LE_ProcessStep>                      <gmd:description>                         <gco:CharacterString>Vector processing procedure: 1. Breaklines acquired from the Lidar data set were used to separate land and water features, thus defining the shoreline. 2. The LIDAR breaklines were transformed into polygons, which took several steps. 3. The breaklines were processed by quarter quad within the coastal zone, and the quarter quad boundaries were joined with the breaklines. Breaklines often had to be extended to close the polygons. 4. After converting the lines into area polygons, the polygons were attributed as either land or water using orthoimagery as the reference. 5. The water polygons were selected out and used to define the land/water shoreline. 6. The water polygons were dissolved across quarter-quadrangle boundaries to form the water areas within each coastal zone basin. 7. The water polygons were converted to polylines, which served as the feature for the shoreline elevation attribute. 8. The water boundary polylines were split into the smallest segments between vertices.</gco:CharacterString>                      </gmd:description>                      <gmd:dateTime>                         <gco:DateTime>9999-01-01T00:00:00</gco:DateTime>                      </gmd:dateTime>                      <gmd:processor>                         <gmd:CI_ResponsibleParty>                            <gmd:individualName>                               <gco:CharacterString>DeWitt Braud and Elaine Evers</gco:CharacterString>                            </gmd:individualName>                            <gmd:organisationName>                               <gco:CharacterString>Louisiana State University, School of The Coast and Environment</gco:CharacterString>                            </gmd:organisationName>                            <gmd:contactInfo>                               <gmd:CI_Contact>                                  <gmd:phone>                                     <gmd:CI_Telephone>                                        <gmd:voice>                                           <gco:CharacterString>225.578.6177 and 225.578.6363</gco:CharacterString>                                        </gmd:voice>                                     </gmd:CI_Telephone>                                  </gmd:phone>                                  <gmd:address>                                     <gmd:CI_Address>                                        <gmd:deliveryPoint>                                           <gco:CharacterString>Louisiana State University</gco:CharacterString>                                        </gmd:deliveryPoint>                                        <gmd:city>                                           <gco:CharacterString>Baton Rouge</gco:CharacterString>                                        </gmd:city>                                        <gmd:administrativeArea>                                           <gco:CharacterString>LA</gco:CharacterString>                                        </gmd:administrativeArea>                                        <gmd:postalCode>                                           <gco:CharacterString>70803</gco:CharacterString>                                        </gmd:postalCode>                                        <gmd:country>                                           <gco:CharacterString>USA</gco:CharacterString>                                        </gmd:country>                                        <gmd:electronicMailAddress>                                           <gco:CharacterString>dbraud1@lsu.edu and eevers@lsu.edu</gco:CharacterString>                                        </gmd:electronicMailAddress>                                     </gmd:CI_Address>                                  </gmd:address>                                  <gmd:hoursOfService>                                     <gco:CharacterString>0800-1630 CST</gco:CharacterString>                                  </gmd:hoursOfService>                               </gmd:CI_Contact>                            </gmd:contactInfo>                            <gmd:role>                               <gmd:CI_RoleCode codeList="http://www.ngdc.noaa.gov/metadata/published/xsd/schema/resources/Codelist/gmxCodelists.xml#CI_RoleCode"                                                codeListValue="processor">processor</gmd:CI_RoleCode>                            </gmd:role>                         </gmd:CI_ResponsibleParty>                      </gmd:processor>                   </gmi:LE_ProcessStep>                </gmd:processStep>                <gmd:processStep>                   <gmi:LE_ProcessStep>                      <gmd:description>                         <gco:CharacterString>Raster processing procedure utilized for each basin 1. The coastal Lidar mosaic was subset to each watershed basin within the official coastal zone boundary. 2. A model was run to convert the floating point values to positive unsigned 16-bit integers for processing. 3. Using the water polygons derived from the breaklines, the water data were subset from the converted Lidar DEM. 4. Since the water extraction and subset process unavoidably includes random land pixels along the water boundary, a filtering process is used to remove the edge land pixels. 5. The filtered Lidar water is used to mask the water from 16-bit Lidar image so that a 3x3 mean filter can be calculated on the land values. 6. A one pixel proximity boundary is calculated along the water perimeter to obtain the landward raster shoreline which is used as a mask. 7. The raster shoreline mask is used to extract the mean shoreline boundary from the mean 16-bit image. 8. The raster shoreline means are converted to a point vector using the pixel centers and the grid-code value to assign to the point attribute value. 9. The pixel point vector file with the elevation values was spatially joined to the split shoreline segments so that the grid-code value (16-bit elevation) of the nearest point was assigned to each segment. The segment thus acquired the elevation value of the nearest cell and the distance to that cell as attributes. 10. The spatial join procedure was accomplished independently for each quarter quad because of the very large number of points and segments to be associated. The number of features processed per minute was far greater with smaller input files. It would otherwise have required a super-computer. 11. Segments with distances to nearest point greater than 7 meters were dropped because they are not close enough to a point to have a valid cell value assigned. 12. The 16-bit grid code value was reverted back to a proper signed floating point elevation value in the shoreline segment attribute table using a formula that reversed the original conversion to unsigned integer. 13. The individual elevation tagged shoreline segment quarter quad panels were merged for each basin limited to the coastal zone boundary to complete the final product.</gco:CharacterString>                      </gmd:description>                      <gmd:dateTime>                         <gco:DateTime>9999-01-01T00:00:00</gco:DateTime>                      </gmd:dateTime>
